steps.title: Start with 1 cup (150 g) of all-purpose flour.
steps.content: Start with 1 cup (150 g) of all-purpose flour. Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl. If your recipe calls for more flour, simply increase the proportions.

steps.title: Add 1½ teaspoons (6 g) of fresh baking powder.
steps.content: Add 1½ teaspoons (6 g) of fresh baking powder. Make sure that the baking powder is fresh. If the baking powder is not fresh, your self-rising flour will not work as well.

steps.title: Add ¼ to ½ teaspoon (1.4-2.8 g) of salt.
steps.content: Add ¼ to ½ teaspoon (1.4-2.8 g) of salt. Take a look at your recipe. If your recipe already contains salt, about ¼ teaspoon (1.4 g) of salt added to your all-purpose flour will do. If your recipe does not contain salt, bump it up to ½ teaspoon (2.8 g) of salt.

steps.title: Include ¼ teaspoon (1.25 g) of baking soda if your recipe calls for buttermilk, cocoa, or yogurt.
steps.content: Include ¼ teaspoon (1.25 g) of baking soda if your recipe calls for buttermilk, cocoa, or yogurt. These ingredients require a little extra raising power. The baking soda (in addition to the baking powder) will give them just that. [2] X Research source If you are not baking with buttermilk, cocoa, or yogurt, you do not need to add the baking soda.

steps.title: Sift the ingredients together to make sure they are evenly combined.
steps.content: Sift the ingredients together to make sure they are evenly combined. Use a whisk or fork to mix them together.

steps.title: Use the flour in your recipe.
steps.content: Use the flour in your recipe. Keep in mind, however, that store-bought self-rising flour is made from a slightly different wheat. Whatever you are baking will not be quite as tender. You should be able to use your homemade self-rising flour for a variety of recipes calling for standard self-rising flour, including biscuits and dumplings .

steps.title: Store any leftover flour in an airtight container, and write the expiration date.
steps.content: Store any leftover flour in an airtight container, and write the expiration date. Note the expiration date on your baking powder. This is when your self-rising flour will expire too. Copy the expiration date from your baking soda into your self-rising flour container. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Combine the flours in a large mixing bowl.
steps.content: Combine the flours in a large mixing bowl. You’ll need 1 ¼ cup (170 g) of brown rice flour, 1 ¼ cup (205 g) of white rice flour, 1 cup (120 g) of tapioca flour, and 1 cup (165 g) of sweet/glutinous rice flour. Mix them together using a whisk or fork until they are evenly combined.

steps.title: Add the xanthan gum.
steps.content: Add the xanthan gum. You will need just a little less than 2 teaspoons (15 g). [4] X Research source Again, make sure that you mix it in well.

steps.title: Prepare the rising agent.
steps.content: Prepare the rising agent. In a separate bowl, combine the baking powder and the salt. You will need about 6 ¾ teaspoons (31 g) of baking powder and 1 ⅛ teaspoon (6.3 g) of salt. If you won't be using all of your gluten-free flour mix, use 1 ½ teaspoons (6 g) of baking powder and ¼ teaspoon (1.4 g) of salt for each 1 cup (120 g) of flour. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Sift the rising agent into the flour.
steps.content: Sift the rising agent into the flour. Mix the two together using a whisk or fork until everything is evenly combined.

steps.title: Use the flour in your recipe, and store any leftover flour in an airtight container.
steps.content: Use the flour in your recipe, and store any leftover flour in an airtight container. Take note of the expiration date on your box of baking powder. This is when your self-rising flour will expire. You might want to copy this date down onto the container you will be keeping your flour in. When you are done, put the container in a cool, dark place.
